bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harry Clemons, September 22, 1939

div1.p: Kean writes Clemons about the Reed - Finlay controversy, and wants to make sure credit is given to both men. Kean submits testimony indicating that Finlay claimed the mosquito as the agent for the spread of yellow fever, and consequently certainly deserves more acknowledgement in U.S. accounts of the yellow fever investigation. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

Sept. 22, 1939
My dear Mr. Clemons:
div1.p:
It seems unreasonable to expect you to take
interest in matters that happened nearly four decades
ago in Cuba, when such great and terrible events
are occurring every day in Europe. But I excuse myself
with the fact that this correspondence, which was
started by your calling my attention to the article
on Moran by Furnas in the Saturday evening Post,
is of some historical importance as bearing on a
matter which has, in Cuba at least, become a sub-
ject of controversy. I would like that the great
Library of which you are the head should contain an
authoritative statement of the facts in the case
Reed and Finlay page 2
of the relative credit which should be given Reed
and Finlay.

It happens that I am, so far as I know, the only
person now living who knew well both Major Walter
Reed and Dr. Carlos J. Finlay and who was present
in an official position of importance at the time and
place of occurrence of the events concerned. Therefore
I should like to place in your library a statement which
will assist future students to judge fairly the re-
spective merits of these two eminent and admirable men
in bringing to light the true method of transmission
of Yellow Fever.

I became acquainted with Dr. Finlay during the
First Intervention 1898 - 1902 when he was the leading
Cuban member of the Yellow Fever Diagnosis Board
of which Gorgas also was a member the latter,
being at that time the Chief Sanitary Officer of the
City of Havana. During the Second Intervention 1906 - 1909
Dr. Finlay was Chief Sanitary Officer of the Island
and President of the National Board of Health and
of the Yellow Fever Diagnosis Board. During all
Reed and Finlay page 3
this period I was constantly associated with him and
was, as the American Government's representative, his
superior officer under the modest title of Advisor
to the Sanitary Department. Our relations were most
cordial and I became much attached personally
to this kindly and learned old man. He let me
take home and study his note books in which were
carefully noted the records of his experiments in
the transmission of Yellow Fever by the bites of
mosquitos, extending over many years prior to the
Spanish American War. He had correctly fixed
the blame on the true culprit mosquito, the common
house mosquito of the tropics, then called Culex
Fasciatus, Fabr. and later Stegomyia. Now it
is called Aëdes/Aegypti. He had also developed
a technique for transporting them in test tubes
and applying them to the skin of the infected patient
and of the receptive non immune. He supported
his theory of transmission by this mosquito with
sound epidemiological arguments and believed
Reed and Finlay page 4
that he had made a number of experimental infections
in this way. In this however it was easy to see
that he was mistaken, as I pointed out to him, for not
one of his cases got by the two hurdles which were
discovered by Lazear and Reed, after the latter's study
of H. R. Carter's observations on what he afterwards
called intrinsic and extrinsic incubation of the
infection. The first unsuspected hurdle was that
the yellow fever patient can only infect the mosquito
in the first three days of the disease. When he
begins to get yellow and the diagnosis is clear
the blood is no longer infective. The second hurdle
was equally upsetting to the unwarned experimenter.
The mosquito after having bitten the yellow fever
patient, if applied to the nonimmune volunteer
at once or for twelve or more days thereafter,
will not cause infection. If the insect is applied
after twelve, or in cool weather, fifteen days
Reed and Finlay page 5
to a non immune an attack follows.

Dr. Finlay had no suspicion of these hurdles
and so he did not produce any experimental case.
Some of his cases, in which their movements were
not controlled, afterwards were attacked but only
after a much longer period than was found in
properly controlled experiments. That Dr.
Finlay kept his faith in his theory unshaken
by the unbelief and ridicule of all his pro-
fessional brethren was an instance, as Gorgas
used to say, of “wonderful scientific clair-
voyance”.

When Major Reed arrived in Cuba on June 25, 1900
to organize his Yellow Fever Board there was
not a doctor in Havana, so far as I know, who
had any faith in Finlay's mosquito theory of the
transmission of yellow fever. But even before
the publication of the Camp Lazear experiments
the cases of Carroll and Lazear and of Private
Reed and Finlay page 6
W. H. Dean, Seventh Cavalry had convinced the members
of the Yellow Fever Board and those who kept abreast
of the facts of the truth of the Finlay Theory. Ac-
cordingly Dr. Juan Guiteras, the Director of
Las Animas Hospital, where the yellow fever
cases were treated, got up a dinner in honor of
Dr. Finlay to celebrate the verification by the
Reed Board of the Finlay theory. It may be said
that there was no Cuban physician at that time
better known and more esteemed by the medical
profession in both Cuba and the United States
than Dr. Guiteras. Born in Cuba, educated
in the United States, he had given up a professor-
ship at the University of Pennsylvania to re-
turn to his native land after its liberation.
About sixty of the leading doctors in Havana
were present as were General Wood the Military
Governor, the members of the Reed Board, Colonel Gorgas
Reed and Finlay page 7
and some other Americans. I sat on Dr. Finlay's right
and, as he spoke English perfectly, had much pleasant
talk with him. Dr. Guiteras, who presided, made a
Charming address, reviewing Dr. Finlay's work and
Major Reed's recent demonstration of the agency
of the mosquito, as claimed for so many years by
Finlay. He said that as regards the credit to
be given to Finlay and Reed respectively he thought
it was quite like the discovery of the mosquito trans-
mission of malaria. This was announced an-
thoritatively by Manson, supported by good epidemiological
reasons, and later Major Ronald Ross of the
British Medical Service in India made the laboratory
demonstration of Manson's theory, tracing the de-
velopment of the malarial parasite in the mos-
quito after she had bitten a case of malaria
and then its transmission by the bite of the mosquito
to another person. Guiteras said that the
scientific world had found no difficulty in giving
Reed and Finlay page 8
due credit to each of them and so it should be with
Finlay and Reed. Both of them seemed quite satis-
fied with this statement of the case, as did the
other guests and Dr. Finlays face beamed with
happiness. I have often used this analogy
in discussing the matter with Cubans and de-
scribed this dinner in my letter to Mr. Moran
to which he refers in the fifth paragraph of
the letter enclosed. This dinner was given
in Havana on December 22, 1900, three days
before Moran was taken sick with yellow fever.
But Private Kissinger of the Hospital Corps, U.S. Army
and three Spaniards had been infected experiment-
ally, under rigidly controlled conditions at Camp
Lazear. The diagnosis had been verified in
each case by the Havana Yellow Fever, Diagnosis Board,
most if not all of the members of which were
present at this dinner.

When Americans feel irritated at exhibitions of
partisanship in a question of medical history, as in
the case of Dr. Dominguez Roldan as described
in paragraph 5 of Mr. Moran's letter enclosed
they should remember that Finlay's name is often
omitted or slightingly referred to in American
Medical publications. I have recently observed
that in the excellent treatise on Internal Medicine
by Dr. John H. Musser of Tulane University
(Lea & Febiger, Phila. 1932) under Yellow Fever
page 184 Finlay's name does not appear in
the 38 lines devoted to history.

I have had no communication from Dr. Philip
H. Hench of the Mayo Clinic (see par. 4 of
Moran's letter). If he should visit the
Alderman Library, I hope that you will
call his attention to this correspondence.

It is regretted that the lack of a typist has
obliged me to put this communication in long hand,
a form which is not attractive to the reader and
is certainly very laborious to the writer.

If at any time you should have occasion
to have copies of the correspondence made
I would be grateful if you would send me
a carbon copy as I have none of either
letter.
